XRP can do whatever any other crypto can do. But just like Bitcoin, it's only a tool. Somebody actually has to put in some work.
Ripple is *not* a "Bitcoin-like" solution. It's not designed for a world of zero-knowledge no-trust assumptions.
Not really. Ripple doesn't want millions of end user wallets on the network. It's not a consumer-facing product.
But by opening a Ripple wallet in Poloniex, users have to pay the reserve XRP, but don't "own" the address as intended by the reserve.
I'm still trying to figure out why Poloniex makes users open up Ripple wallets that users can't control. It doesn't many any sense.
Ripple is XRP, not XMR.
I should probably put in my bio that the technology interests me, not the price. Bitcoin at $1 isn't less interesting than Bitcoin at $2700.
